chapter.title: Using SystemTap
chapter.para: This chapter instructs users how to install SystemTap, and provides an introduction on how to run SystemTap scripts.

section.title: Usage
section.remark: - basic commands (e.g. stap), useful options per command (e.g. stap -vv), tool references (man pages, related kernel-doc), references within book (i.e. errors chapter)
section.para: SystemTap scripts are run through the command stap. stap can run SystemTap scripts from standard input or from file.

important.title: Important
important.para: Running SystemTap requires root privileges. As such, you need to either log in as root or configure sudo accordingly for specific users who need to run SystemTap (refer to man sudo or man visudo for more information.

section.para: Below is a list of commonly used stap options:

To run SystemTap instrumentation (i.e. the kernel module built from SystemTap scripts during a cross-instrumentation), use staprun instead. For more information about staprun and cross-instrumentation, refer to .

note.title: Note
note.para: The stap options -v and -o also work for staprun. For more information about staprun, refer to man staprun.

formalpara.title: stapdev and stapusr
formalpara.para: Running stap and staprun requires elevated privileges to the system. However, not all users can be granted root access just to run SystemTap. In some cases, for instance, you may want to allow a non-privileged user to run SystemTap instrumentation on his machine.

section.para: To allow ordinary users to run SystemTap without root access, add them to one of these user groups:

listitem.para: Members of this group can use stap to run SystemTap scripts, or staprun to run SystemTap instrumentation modules.

Members of this group can only run staprun to run SystemTap instrumentation modules. In addition, they can only run those modules from /lib/modules/kernel_version/systemtap/. Note that this directory must be owned only by the root user, and must only be writable by the root user.
